instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TW0P Sensor Error
threads.message:
Hello,

This board has no liquid damage. It had intermittent kernel panics and shutdowns until I addressed bad solder joints at <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>. 
It is failing diagnostics with sensor error TW0P, which I think is airport proximity temp. Fans do not spin on high, however.
I checked for 3.3V at <CHIP>U5523</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>. Replaced <CHIP>U5570</CHIP> to test, no changes to behavior. Checked data lines <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_1_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> and SCL, no oscilloscope available but fluctuations on those lines indicate that there is some kind of modulation (data?) on those lines. 
Any thoughts? Replacing <CHIP>U5523</CHIP> will be a pain due to connectors in that area, would it be better to bottom heat?
Or is it the SMC?

Thanks,

Stefan

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TW0P Sensor Error
threads.message: If there is not enough information, or if I am being an idiot, please feel free to let me know as well. I'll take any chance to learn!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TW0P Sensor Error
threads.message: If no other sensor is failing I say bad <CHIP>U5523</CHIP>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TW0P Sensor Error
threads.message:
Please mark post as resolved. Replaced <CHIP>U5523</CHIP> and the issue was resolved. I looked at it under high magnification and the top looked a little funny.. almost like a chip was taken out of the top of it. 
Pain in the neck to replace that particular component surrounded by the fan, IO board, and wifi connectors.
